message_1: Suppose the height of a certain population follows a normal distribution with a mean of 68 inches and a standard deviation of 3 inches. If a sample of 36 individuals is taken, what is the probability that the sample mean height is greater than 69 inches?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the concept of the sampling distribution of the sample mean. According to the Central Limit Theorem, the sampling distribution of the sample mean for a large enough sample size (n ≥ 30) will be approximately normally distributed, regardless of the underlying population distribution.

In this case, the population mean (μ) is 68 inches, and the population standard deviation (σ) is 3 inches. The sample size (n) is 36 individuals.

The mean of the sampling distribution of the sample mean (μx̄) is equal to the population mean (μ):

μx̄ = μ = 68 inches

The standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the sample mean (σx̄) is equal to the population standard deviation (σ) divided by the square root of the sample size (n):

σx̄ = σ / √n = 3 / √36 = 3 / 6 = 0.5 inches

Now, we want to find the probability that the sample mean height is greater than 69 inches. To do this, we will calculate the z-score corresponding to a sample mean of 69 inches:

z = (x̄ - μx̄) / σx̄ = (69 - 68) / 0.5 = 1 / 0.5 = 2

A z-score of 2 means that the sample mean of 69 inches is 2 standard deviations above the mean of the sampling distribution of the sample mean.

Now, we will use the standard normal distribution table (also known as the z-table) to find the probability that the z-score is greater than 2. The value corresponding to a z-score of 2 in the z-table is 0.9772. This value represents the probability that the z-score is less than 2. To find the probability that the z-score is greater than 2, we subtract this value from 1:

P(z > 2) = 1 - P(z < 2) = 1 - 0.9772 = 0.0228

So, the probability that the sample mean height is greater than 69 inches is approximately 0.0228, or 2.28%.
